articles.title: OCTOBER 1987
articles.summary: This document outlines a series of astronomical events and meetings for October and November 1987. Key events include a general meeting on October 3rd featuring Robert Wagoner discussing Supernova SN1987A, multiple field expeditions to Fremont Peak State Park, and an introductory astronomy class. The schedule also includes board meetings and a November indoor star party.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article announces two significant upcoming astronomical events: the annual conference of the Astronomical Association of Northern California (AANC) taking place September 18-20 at the Lawrence Hall of Science, Berkeley, featuring talks on astronomy, equipment, and astrophotography. Additionally, it details the SJAA's October 3rd General Meeting, where Stanford Professor Robert Wagoner will lecture on supernovae, specifically discussing supernova 1987a and its use as a 'standard candle' for determining the Hubble constant.

articles.title: ASTRO CLASS TO MEET AT PLANETARIUM
articles.summary: The Introductory Astronomy Class, led by Jack Ziders, will convene at the West Valley College Planetarium on October 11th at 8:30 PM. The session will continue the survey of the night sky, with students advised to proceed directly to the planetarium instead of the usual meeting spot.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: The article features classified advertisements for astronomical equipment, including a refractor, focuser, eyepiece, and optical windows, alongside a reward for a stolen mirror. It also provides a detailed personal account of the 5th Annual Yosemite Star Party, describing the journey, campground conditions, observations of climbers, and two nights of stargazing with various telescopes for hundreds to thousands of attendees, highlighting a successful second night despite initial cloud cover.

articles.title: SHUTTLE RECOVERY MAKING PROGRESS
articles.summary: The shuttle recovery effort is progressing, with a successful full-scale test of the new booster joint completed and more scheduled. Engines for the orbiter Discovery are undergoing acceptance testing for the first resumption flight, expected to finish by December. Additionally, work on a replacement orbiter began in August, with delivery anticipated by April 1991.

articles.title: NASA STUDYING UPGRADED SHUTTLE COMPONENTS
articles.summary: NASA is actively studying upgrades for Space Shuttle components to enhance performance in the 1990s. Contracts have been awarded to five companies to design an advanced solid rocket motor, with a lightweight filament-wound motor case successfully exceeding test requirements and promising increased payload capacity. Additionally, improvements to the orbiter engine's turbo machinery are under investigation.

articles.title: SPACE STATION FACES FUNDING PROBLEMS
articles.summary: Senator Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee controlling NASA's budget, is actively attempting to cancel the space station project, causing concern within NASA. Following this, some NASA officials illegally urged industry to lobby Congress in support of the space station, leading to an apology from Administrator James Fletcher and potential criminal charges for those involved due to the misuse of government funds for lobbying.

articles.title: CHINESE SPACECRAFT CONDUCTS ZERO-G MATERIALS PROCESSING
articles.summary: The China 20 spacecraft successfully conducted zero-gravity materials processing experiments in space. It obtained valuable data on the smelting and recrystallization of various materials, including alloys, semiconductors, and recently conceived superconductor materials.

articles.title: JAPANESE LAUNCH SECOND H-1 BOOSTER
articles.summary: Japan successfully launched its second H-1 booster on August 27, deploying the ETS-5 engineering test satellite into a geosynchronous transfer orbit. The H-1 rocket features a cryogenic second stage and a newly developed solid-propellant third stage.

articles.title: JAPAN TO DEVELOP THREE ADVANCED SPACECRAFT
articles.summary: The Japanese Space Agency has approved the development of three advanced spacecraft missions. These include the 5500 lb Advanced Earth Observation Satellite (ADEOS) for 1993, a 4400 lb Experimental Data Relay Tracking Satellite for 1994, and an Advanced Geosynchronous Meteorological Satellite also planned for 1993.

articles.title: SOVIETS PLAN MISSION TO AN ASTEROID
articles.summary: The Soviets are reportedly planning an asteroid mission for the mid-1990s, aiming to deploy probes onto the surface. Concurrently, a U.S. comet rendezvous asteroid flyby (CRAF) mission has been proposed for fiscal year 1989, though it is not designed for direct surface sampling.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article reports on the discovery of two new comets by amateur astronomers and the recovery of a faint periodic comet. Comet Bradfield (1987s), the discoverer's thirteenth, is expected to become visible in binoculars, reaching magnitude five in November. Comet Rudenko (1987u), the discoverer's second, will be visible at magnitude 7-9 in the morning sky during October and November, while Periodic Comet Jackson-Neujmin (1987t) is too faint for amateur observation.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides detailed ephemerides for two comets, Comet Bradfield (1987s) and Comet Rudenko (1987u), covering late September to early November. It lists their celestial coordinates (R.A. and Dec.), elongation, magnitude, and observational notes, encouraging astronomers to view their progression and brightening in the evening and morning skies, respectively.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p)
articles.summary: The article provides an observation guide for Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p) from late September to mid-November, detailing its changing position, magnitude, and visibility. It describes the comet's steady brightening, increase in size, and condensation as it traces a 'strange little loop' through the southern morning sky. The comet is noted as one of three visible in binoculars during this period.

articles.title: Comet Wilson (1986L)
articles.summary: The article presents an observation log for Comet Wilson (1986L) covering late September to mid-November, detailing its position, azimuth, and visual magnitude. It notes the comet's appearance in the morning sky, its continued dimming, and its considerable distance from both the Sun and Earth. The comet is described as remaining small (1-2 arc-minutes) and faint (magnitude 11.1-11.8), similar to its state at the time of its discovery 14 months earlier.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: The 1986 "Catalogue of Cometary Orbits" by Dr. Brian Marsden details 1187 apparitions of 748 comets, with 18% identified as periodic. These periodic comets typically have an average orbital period of 7.1 years, a perihelion distance of 1.5 AU, and an inclination of 13 degrees. Many recent periodic comet discoveries are faint, photographic finds near the ecliptic, characterized by nearly circular orbits and low intrinsic magnitude.

articles.title: AN OVERVIEW OF OBSERVING SITES BY DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: This article provides a comprehensive overview of Fremont Peak State Park as a popular observing site for amateur astronomers in Central California. It details driving directions, various telescope setup locations within the park, fees, typical weather conditions, sky quality, and potential challenges like light pollution, wildlife, and crowds. Despite some drawbacks, the park is highlighted as a great place for amateur astronomers to gather and observe.

articles.title: VISIT THE HUBBLE SPACE TELESCOPE
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is offering its members an exclusive opportunity to visit and view the Hubble Space Telescope at Lockheed in Sunnyvale before its launch. Two dates, November 6 and 9, are available, with a limit of 30 attendees per session, requiring advance sign-up with Bob Fingerhut and adherence to specific regulations.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, featuring speakers on various astronomical topics and informal "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share interests. These meetings foster a friendly atmosphere for enthusiasts of astrophotography, deep sky observation, telescope making, and general observing. The article also provides detailed directions and timing for the meetings.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The article describes monthly "Indoor Star Parties" as informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers. These events allow members to share telescopes and accessories, view astrophotography, socialize, and discuss astronomy. Additionally, the SJAA conducts Board Meetings and an Introductory Astronomy workshop during these times.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon. These events take place at various designated locations, ranging from sites close to San Jose to more distant places like Yosemite National Park. Attendees are advised to check the EPHEMERIS for directions to these expedition sites.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular observing site for Bay Area amateur astronomers, favored for deep sky observing and astrophotography during New Moon weekends, often hosting 50-100 telescopes. The park is home to the Fremont Peak Observatory Association's 30-inch public telescope and serves as a primary setup area for the San Jose Astronomical Association, with detailed directions provided. The article also includes contact information for the San Jose Astronomical Association's officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details different membership types and their associated fees, including options for Membership Only, Membership with Sky & Telescope subscription, and Junior membership. The form requests personal contact information and provides instructions for submission to the SJAA treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire designed to gather information on individuals' astronomical interests, inquire about telescope ownership, and identify areas where they might be qualified to assist others. It also includes contact and mailing information for the 'SJAA Ephemeris' in San Jose, CA, indicating it as dated news material from a non-profit organization.
